title: The Ca<sup>2+</sup>-activated K<sup>+</sup> current of human sperm is mediated by Slo3
abstract: Sperm are equipped with a unique set of ion channels that orchestrate fertilization. In mouse sperm, the principal K<sup>+</sup> current (I<sub>KSper</sub>) is carried by the Slo3 channel, which sets the membrane potential (V<sub>m</sub>) in a strongly pH<sub>i</sub>-dependent manner. Here, we show that I<sub>KSper</sub> in human sperm is activated weakly by pH<sub>i</sub> and more strongly by Ca<sup>2+</sup>. Correspondingly, V<sub>m</sub> is strongly regulated by Ca<sup>2+</sup> and less so by pH<sub>i</sub>. We find that inhibitors of Slo3 suppress human I<sub>KSper</sub>, and we identify the Slo3 protein in the flagellum of human sperm. Moreover, heterologously expressed human Slo3, but not mouse Slo3, is activated by Ca<sup>2+</sup> rather than by alkaline pH<sub>i</sub>; current–voltage relations of human Slo3 and human I<sub>KSper</sub> are similar. We conclude that Slo3 represents the principal K<sup>+</sup> channel in human sperm that carries the Ca<sup>2+</sup>-activated I<sub>KSper</sub> current. We propose that, in human sperm, the progesterone-evoked Ca<sup>2+</sup> influx carried by voltage-gated CatSper channels is limited by Ca<sup>2+</sup>-controlled hyperpolarization via Slo3.
